#â€‹762 â€” November 21, 2025

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

Google Announces Angular v21 â€” The Google team has gone all out with this significant release of its popular JavaScript framework. Theyâ€™ve put together a retro game-themed adventure-based tour of whatâ€™s new, along with top notch videos showing off features like its new signal-based approach to forms, MCP server for AI-powered workflows, library of headless components focused on accessibility, and even a new â€˜Angular AI Tutorâ€™ to get up toÂ speed.

Google

Authentication. Complete, Not Complex â€”

const fusionAuth = {Â

};

FusionAuth sponsor

IN BRIEF:

  • Devographics' annual State of React survey is now open to take again. Here's last year'sÂ results.

  • ğŸ¤ TypeScript's Daniel Rosenwasser and Jake Bailey went on the TypeScript.fm podcast to talk about what's coming up in TypeScript 6 andÂ 7.

  • ğŸ“— TC-39 member James M. Snell is working on a book called JavaScript in Depth for Manning. Final publication is expected in mid 2026 but four chapters are already available in earlyÂ access.

  • CSS Grid support should be coming to React Native soon.

RELEASES:

  • Prisma 7.0 â€“ Popular ORM for Node.js andÂ TypeScript. The Rust-free Prisma Client is now theÂ default.

  • pnpm 10.23 â€“ Fast, space efficient packageÂ manager.

  • Node.js v25.2.1 (Current), Astro 5.16

ğŸ“–Â  Articles and Videos

Photo used with the kind permission of Rob Palmer

This week's TC39 meeting: The Ecma TC39 committee (the group behind the design of ECMAScript / JavaScript) met up for the 111th time this week (seen above) to discuss language proposals. The meeting notes won't be published for a few weeks, but several proposals did see some progress:

  • Iterator Sequencing progressed to stage 4.

  • Joint Iteration, Iterator Join, and Await dictionary of Promises go stage 2.7.

  • Error.captureStackTrace, import .. with {type: "text"}, and Object.keysLength all progressed to stage 2.

  • The Intl Unit Protocol also reached stage 1 to provide a way to annotate quantities with the units being measured.

  • Typed Array Find Within progressed to stage 1. Think a native indexOf-type method for TypedArrays.

Note: Learn more about what the TC39 stages meanÂ here.

Tooltip Components Should Not Exist â€” Dominik challenges some common wisdom in his typically erudite fashion. Stand-alone tooltip components are the wrong abstraction when separated from the underlying UI features that use them. This thinking can apply to many other UI affordances too, so the broad idea is well worthÂ considering.

Dominik Dorfmeister (AKA TkDodo)

Agentic Postgres: Let Your Agents Cook â€” Build AI apps faster: Postgres with built-in memory, search, and free forkable DBs. Try it free onÂ Tiger.

Tiger Data sponsor

Implementing Wordle in LibreOffice with JavaScript Macros â€” One of those fun things where the real value is in learning that you can script LibreOffice withÂ JavaScript.

Bojidar Marinov

Automated NPM Secret Rotation in GitHub Actions â€” If youâ€™ve built a system to automatically publish to npm, you may have had to change things due to this monthâ€™s npm security changes. Hereâ€™s a way to keep things ticking if youâ€™re not ready to switch to trustedÂ publishing.

Michael Heap

Six Things I Bet You Didn't Know You Could Do With Chrome's DevTools â€” Part one here covers the first three, with part two covering the last three. Covers time functions, DOM observation, user action replays, andÂ more.

Rachel Kaufman

ğŸ“„ An Experiment in Making TypeScript Immutable-by-Default â€“ â€œI wondered: is it possible to make TypeScript values immutable byÂ default?â€ Evan Hahn

ğŸ“„ How to Build Cinematic 3D Scroll Experiences with GSAP Joseph Santamaria

ğŸ“„ How We Migrated 76,000 Tests from Enzyme to React Testing Library â€“ HubSpotâ€™s tale of a big React testingÂ migration. Charley Pugmire (HubSpot)

ğŸ“„ How to 'Officially' Deprecate Methods in Node.js Code â€“ Did you know of Node's deprecate method? Stefan Judis

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

Webpack Bundle Analyzer 5.0: A Visual Look at Webpack's Output â€” An official Webpack plugin and CLI tool that shows bundle content in the form of an interactive zoomable treemap so you can dig in and see whatâ€™s taking up space in your bundle (and then optimize it, ideally).

Webpack Project

TanStack DB 0.5, Now with Query-Driven Sync â€” TanStackâ€¯DB is a clientâ€‘first reactive data store that uses differential dataflow to power live, relational queries, subâ€‘ms incremental updates, and seamless optimistic writes. In v0.5, a componentâ€™s query becomes the API call too. â€œJust write your query and TanStack DB figures out exactly what toÂ fetch.â€

Willis, De Parre, and Matthews

Still Writing Tests Manually? â€” See why modern engineering teams like Dropbox, Notion and Lattice rely on Meticulous to run E2E UIÂ tests.

Meticulous AI sponsor

Brimstone: A New JavaScript Engine Written in Rust â€” Joining the hundreds of JS engines available, Brimstone has strong language support (97% of the spec), is very small, but remains a work inÂ progress.

Hans Halverson

VueFinder: File Management Component for Vue 3 â€” Provides a reactive, native-like file explorer interface for users to organize, preview, and manageÂ files.

Yusuf Ã–zdemir

is-online 12.0: Check if the Internet Connection Is Up â€” Works in both Node and the browser and uses various approaches to check if the Internet is reallyÂ available.

Sindre Sorhus

  • PlayCanvas glTF Viewer 5.7 â€“ 3D model viewer supporting glTF 2.0 andÂ PLY.

  • Wasp 0.19 â€“ Wasp is a Rails-like framework built on Node, React &Â Prisma.

  • Neo.mjs 11.7 â€“ Multi-threaded framework for fast, desktop-likeÂ webapps.

  • Inquirer.js 13.0 â€“ Popular interactive CLI controls library forÂ Node.js.

  • Plotly.js 3.3 â€“ Standalone data visualizationÂ library.

  • Rockpack 7.0 â€“ React appÂ starter/generator.

  • Fresh 2.2 â€“ Deno-powered WebÂ framework.

ğŸ“°Â Classifieds

Build Docker images faster with BuildKit and Depot. Parallel execution, deduplication, and auto-scaling cut CI waitÂ times.

ğŸ¨ Try Pintura image editor for free today, add a polished cropping, rotating, and annotation experience to your web app inÂ minutes.

The Road to Next is a course by Robin Wieruch for learning full-stack web development with Next.js 15 and React 19. The perfect match for JavaScript developers ready to go beyond theÂ frontend.

ğŸ“¢Â  Elsewhere in the ecosystem

Some other interesting tidbits in the broader landscape:

  • Were you affected by Cloudflare's extended outage on Tuesday? If so, you might be keen to learn all the details of what happened (it was code-related). This is a fantastic example of an incident report, despite theÂ inconvenience.

  • ğŸ“— WebAssembly from the Ground Up is a new (paid) book that walks you through building a compiler in JavaScript. There's a sample PDF showing off thirty pages of the content â€“ it looks veryÂ promising.

  • A well-presented account of how a well-known typeface company pursued another company for nonexistent license violations.

  • Josef Strzibny has looked at Reddit's newly unveiled 'engagement' numbers for various programming subreddits. Redditors clearly like to be niche, as /r/node, /r/react and /r/nextjs all easily beat /r/javascript's engagementÂ numbers.

  • The above autocorrect-fuelled headline on Hacker News gave me aÂ chuckle. If you like Bach or organ music in general, â–¶ï¸Â listen to the 'new' piecesÂ here.

  • Amazon RDS for PostgreSQL now supports Postgres 18.

ã€

#â€‹761 â€” November 14, 2025

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

JavaScript Engines Zoo: Learn About Over 100 JS Engines â€” Iâ€™m a sucker for a big table of data and this is about as big as it gets when it comes to JavaScript engines. See how various engines compare, sort them by performance, or click on an engineâ€™s name to learn more about its development, history, and end users. The projectâ€™s repo also has Dockerfiles for trying each of themÂ out.

Ivan Krasilnikov

ğŸ’¡ Sticking with a theme, I've always enjoyed this ECMAScript compatibility table where you can see cross-browser and runtime support for different JavaScriptÂ features.

FlexGrid by Wijmo: The Industry-Leading JavaScript Datagrid â€” A fast and flexible datagrid for building modern web apps. Key features and virtualized rendering are included in the core grid module. Pick & choose special features to keep your app small. Built for JavaScript, extended to Angular, React, andÂ Vue.

Wijmo From MESCIUS sponsor

Valdi: Snap's Newly-Open Cross-Platform UI Framework â€” The team behind Snapchat has open sourced this cross-platform UI framework that itâ€™s used in its production apps for eight years: â€œWrite your UI once in declarative TypeScript, and it compiles directly to native views on iOS, Android, and macOSâ€”no web views, no JavaScriptÂ bridges.â€

Snap

ğŸ’¡ Valdi's FAQ answers several questions you might have, including how it works and why you might pick Valdi over ReactÂ Native.

IN BRIEF:

  • The TC39 committee behind ECMAScript is meeting for the 111th time next week and has a packed agenda to discuss. (Thanks to Rob Palmer for the headsÂ up.)

  • For Stack Overflow, Tanya Janca shares several tips for writing more secure JavaScript.

  • The co-founder of the fantastic Val Town online JavaScript platform shares a retrospective of its past three years, as well as two roles they're hiringÂ for.

  • Visual Types is a handy visually-oriented guide/tour of what types are and how they work, with a focus onÂ TypeScript.

RELEASES:

  • Bun v1.3.2 â€“ Isolated package installs, introduced as the default in v1.3, were causing issues with some existing projects, so now hoisted installs are back as the default for those. bun install also gets even faster and you can do CPU profiling by running with --cpu-prof.

  • Node.js v25.2.0 (Current) â€“ Now with type stripping marked as stable.

  • esbuild 0.27 â€“ Popular bundler. A notable release for having breaking changes (so you're reminded to pin esbuild appropriately).

  • TanStack DB 0.5, Node.js v24.11.1 (LTS), MikroORM 6.6

ğŸ“–Â  Articles and Videos

â–¶Â Â The State of Node.js in 2025, Explained â€” A thirty-minute talk from JSNation earlier this year where TSC member Matteo Collina presented an update on Nodeâ€™s still-growing popularity, release schedule, security, recent performance enhancements, the permissions system, andÂ more.

GitNation

V8's Garbage Collector Developments in Recent Years â€” Andy, whoâ€™s worked on both V8 and JavaScriptCore in the past, reviews the major developments in the V8 engineâ€™s garbage collector over the past couple of years. Very technical, but a valuable piece ofÂ history.

Andy Wingo

Build Type-Safe APIs for Your JS Apps: Protobuf Workshop with BufÂ Team â€” Learn how Protobuf brings type safety across your stack from Node.js APIs to frontend clients. Live Q&A with BufÂ engineers.

Buf sponsor

Comparing Electron vs. Tauri for Building and Distributing a DesktopÂ App â€” A team working on an open-source desktop app built using JavaScript and Electron took a look into the Rust-based Tauri instead, with mixed, but mostly positive, results.

Eric Richardson

Using Expo for React Native Development in 2025: A Perspective â€” Expo has essentially become to React Native what Next.js became to React. But is it well suited for you? Jack weighs the pros andÂ cons.

Jack Rosa

ğŸ“„ How We Catch UI Bugs Early with Visual Regression Testing â€“ Using Playwright and its visual comparisons feature. Tommaso Ruscica

ğŸ“º Learn JavaScript by Building 'Mario' â€“ One of Aniaâ€™s typically easy to follow, comprehensiveÂ tutorials. Ania Kubow

ğŸ“„ Building a 3D Infinite Carousel with Reactive Background Gradients ClÃ©ment Grellier

ğŸ“„ Error Chaining in JS: Cleaner Debugging with Error's cause Matt Smith

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

imgui-react-runtime: React + Dear ImGui + Static Hermes â€” When the author teased a demo of this on X a few weeks ago, I wasnâ€™t sure if it would get released, but here it is. A new way to put together native apps using React and the popular lightweight GUI library DearÂ ImGui.

Tzvetan Mikov

ESLint Plugin for Baseline JavaScript â€” The winner of last month's Baseline Tooling Hackathon is an ESLint plugin that flags code thatâ€™s using features newer than your configured Baseline target (features broadly supported by modernÂ browsers).

Ryuya Hasegawa

Customizable JavaScript Libraries for Forms & Surveys â€” Create branded, dynamic forms with full control over design, logic, and dataÂ storage.

SurveyJS sponsor

pnpm 10.21: Safer Installs and Smarter Runtime Management â€” Now installs the Node version required by a dependency, declared in its engines.runtime field, meaning CLI apps and postinstall scripts will run with the specified version. The trustPolicy setting also adds protection against supply-chain attacks by failing to install a package if its trust levelÂ drops.

Zoltan Kochan

Ink 6.5: Build Interactive CLI Apps using React â€” A very widely used terminal-based React renderer for building reactive terminal apps using components. v6.5 is notable for adding an incremental renderingÂ option.

Vadim Demedes

  • vis-timeline 8.4 â€“ Interactive control to visualize data across time, as shown above. Numerous examples here.

  • rasterizeHTML.js 1.4 â€“ Renders HTML into a canvas element. Now supporting OffscreenCanvasÂ too.

  • file-type 21.1 â€“ Detect the file type of a file, stream, orÂ data in both Node and theÂ browser.

  • Svelte SEO 2.0 â€“ Optimize your Svelte app for search engines and socialÂ media.

  • isomorphic-git 1.35 â€“ Pure JS implementation of git for Node &Â browsers.

ğŸ“°Â Classifieds

Add lightning-fast, on-device 1D/2D code scanning to your web app with STRICH. Easy integration, simple pricing, free trial andÂ demo!

Still writing tests manually? See why modern engineering teams like Dropbox, Notion and Lattice rely on Meticulous to run E2E UIÂ tests.

Launch Your Shopify Storefront in Minutes with Next.js - Open-source starter with Dynamic OG Images, AI Vector Search & VercelÂ Toolbar.

ğŸ¨ Try Pintura image editor for free today, add a polished cropping, rotating, and annotation experience to your web app inÂ minutes.

ğŸ“¢Â  Elsewhere in the ecosystem

Some other interesting tidbits in the broader landscape:

  • ğŸ”’ OWASP (Open Worldwide Application Security Project) has released its list of the top ten web application security threats inÂ 2025.

  • ğŸ¤– An ardent critic of LLMs spent a month doing 'chat oriented programming' and while he found the experience "infuriating", he concedes it has merit and is a viable option "if your tolerance for pain is high enough.".

  • ğŸ§Š Ever fancied implementing a voxel-based engine for that Minecraft-esque experience? Uses (very Rust-y) pseudocode in order to remain timeless and let you enjoy doing the implementationÂ yourself.

  • An explanation of the differences between monorepos, multi-repo, submodule and subtree setups inÂ Git.

  • ğŸ’» If you like collecting stickers from conferences, you might enjoy this gallery of hundreds of people's stickered-up laptops or even want to submit yourÂ own. It took me a while to find any JavaScript stickers, but they'reÂ there..

ğŸ‚ P.S. JavaScript Weekly turned fifteen years old this week! Thanks to all of you for reading, and particularly anyone still subscribed from the first issue. We haven't looked at the stats in a while, but we know there are some of you!Â :-)

item.description:
ã€

#â€‹760 â€” November 7, 2025

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

The Inner Workings of JavaScript Source Maps â€” Ever wondered how devtools can magically turn mangled, minified JavaScript back into readable source while debugging? Zero magic; thatâ€™s a source map doing its job. But how do source maps actually work under theÂ hood?

Manoj Vivek

Ship Secure MCP Auth Without Relying on API Keys â€” API keys are hard to scope and break user flows. WorkOS Connect delivers a fully compliant OAuth 2.1 flow. It handles PKCE, scopes, user consent, and secure token issuance out of theÂ box.

WorkOS sponsor

Anders Hejlsberg's Take on the Rise of TypeScript â€” The co-creator of TypeScript says heâ€™s â€˜flooredâ€™ by the languageâ€™s success (now the number one language on GitHub in 2025), shares a little info on the on-going compiler rewrite in Go, and the increasing role ofÂ AI.

The GitHub Blog

Embedding TypeScript with Hako â€” A technical look at the Hako JavaScript engine. It runs in WebAssembly so can be more easily embedded in more environments, including mobileÂ apps.

Andrew Sampson

IN BRIEF:

  • GitHub has updated its post about ongoing npm security changes. npm classic tokens can no longer be created, but existing ones will continue to work till February 3, 2026 at theÂ latest.

  • I enjoyed Lea Verou's cute proxy-based trick for creating symbols on demand.

  • The Svelte team has a November 2025 update on what's new in Svelte.

  • ğŸ‡·ğŸ‡´ The popular JSHeroes conference is taking place in Romania next May 14-15. If you'd like to speak, its CFP is open until DecemberÂ 31.

RELEASES:

  • Storybook 10 â€“ The popular frontend component workshop is now ESM-only, lighter, has a new module automocking system, Vitest 4 support, andÂ more.

  • htmx 4.0 Alpha 1 â€“ There was never going to be a v3 of htmx, so how about v4? Carson Gross tells the full storyÂ here.

  • React Email 5.0 â€“ Suite of components for creating emails in React. Now with a dark mode switcher and Tailwind 4Â support.

  • Turborepo 2.6, Video.js v10, ESLint Config Inspector v1.4

ğŸ“–Â  Articles and Videos

â–¶Â Â The Talk Videos from CascadiaJS 2025 â€” CascadiaJS took place a month ago and the talk videos have been gradually rolling out onto YouTube. You can learn more about TanStack with Jack Herrington, the origin story of JavaScript with Annie Sexton, the Web Monetization API with Ioana Chiorean, andÂ more.

CascadiaJS

High-Performance Syntax Highlighting with the CSS Custom HighlightÂ API â€” Now supported in all major browsers, the CSS Custom Highlight API provides a mechanism for styling arbitrary text ranges in a document by using JavaScript to create the ranges, and CSS to styleÂ them.

Pavitra Golchha

How to Create a Virtual Green Screen Using the Vonage Video API â€” Transform video calls with virtual green screens using the Vonage Video API and HTML5Â canvas.

Vonage sponsor

How to Throttle Specific Requests in ChromeÂ DevTools â€” Chrome DevTools has supported network throttling for a long time but you can now throttle requests to specific URLs or domains too, which could be ideal if you want to see how your site handles the failure of third partyÂ scripts.

Matt Zeunert

?!Â Importing Node Modules from BitTorrent â€” A fascinating demo of the power of Node.jsâ€™s customization hooks for overriding importÂ behavior.

Evan Hahn

Advanced Beginnerâ€™s Guide to ClojureScript â€” An introduction to a compiler for the functional Clojure Lisp dialect that producesÂ JavaScript.

Roman Liutikov

ğŸ“„ Handling Time and Mock Clocks in Tests Andrew Scott (Angular)

ğŸ“„ Zod + TypeScript: Schema Validation Made Easy Hassan Djirdeh

ğŸ“„ Next.js 16: Whatâ€™s New and What It Means for FrontendÂ Devs Abiola Farounbi (LogRocket)

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

Perspective 4.0: High Performance Analytics and Data Visualization Component â€” Originally built by JP Morgan, this data visualization component, built in C++ and compiled to WebAssembly, is well-suited for large and real-time streaming datasets. The demo on the homepage lets you try visualization types at up to 1000 changes per second. v4.0 sees the project move to the OpenJSÂ Foundation.

OpenJS Foundation

ğŸ’¡ Perspective comes with a rich set of examples with full code demonstrating how to use it, like this streaming example.

Agentic Postgres: Let Your Agents Cook â€” Build AI apps faster: Postgres with built-in memory, search, and free forkable DBs. Try it free onÂ Tiger.

Tiger Data sponsor

Vue Data UI 3.6: Vue Components Library for Data Storytelling â€” Thereâ€™s a lot packed into this suite of components, including basic chart types through to donuts, sparklines, world views, stacks, heatmaps, word clouds, and more. Definitely worth a look if youâ€™re using Vue. LiveÂ examples.

Alec Lloyd Probert

ğŸ–¼ï¸Â image-dimensions: Get the Dimensions ofÂ Images â€” A zero-dependency way to get the pixel width and height of JPEG, PNG/APNG, GIF, WebP, AVIF and HEIF images in any modern JavaScriptÂ environment.

Sindre Sorhus

React Syntax Highlighter: A Code Syntax Highlighting Component â€” If you need to show off source code in your React app somewhere, this is a component that does the job. GitHubÂ repo.

Conor Hastings

CSSOM: A CSS Parser Written in Pure JavaScript â€” Also a partial implementation of CSS ObjectÂ Model.

Nikita Vasilyev

  • debounce 3.0 â€“ Delay function calls until a set time elapses after the lastÂ invocation. Now a pure ESÂ module.

  • bcrypt.js 3.0.3 â€“ Optimized bcrypt in pure JavaScript, even in theÂ browser.

  • Marked 17.0 â€“ Markdown parser andÂ compiler. (Docs.)

  • AlaSQL.js 4.8 â€“ Isomorphic JavaScript SQLÂ database.

  • fast-copy 4.0 â€“ A fast deep object copier.

ğŸ“°Â Classifieds

Still writing tests manually? See why modern engineering teams like Dropbox, Notion and Wiz rely on Meticulous to run E2E UIÂ tests.

ğŸ” Search your GitHub Actions logs instantly. No more endless scrolling through CI failures. Try Depot's new log search and find errors inÂ seconds.

ğŸ“¢Â  Elsewhere in the ecosystem

A roundup of some other interesting stories in the broader landscape:

  • In Your URL is Your State, Ahmad Alfy looks at the 'overlooked power' and elegance of using the URL's various components for representing state.

  • Matt Perry shares everything he knows about animation performance on the Web in The Web Animation Performance Tier List.

  • Ben Visness writes about how Mozilla has overhauled its internal tools for visualizing JavaScript and WebAssembly compilation, complete with some interactive graphs.

  • If you were saddened by the recent closure of Glitch, Thomas Steiner demonstrates how to use Hugging Face Spaces as an alternative for hosting small server-based Node apps.

item.description:
ã€

#â€‹759 â€” October 31, 2025

Read on the Web

JavaScript Weekly

Directives and the Platform Boundary â€” First there was the "use strict" directive to opt in to strict mode in JavaScript, but now youâ€™ll encounter use client, use server, React's new use no memo, and more, and they're not standard JS features at all. Tanner thinks this proliferation of directives comes at a cost, with an increased risk of framework and toolingÂ lock-in.

Tanner Linsley (TanStack)

Add Excel-like Spreadsheet Functionality to Your JavaScript Apps â€” SpreadJS is the industry-leading JavaScript spreadsheet for adding advanced spreadsheet features to your enterprise apps. Build finance, analysis, budget, and other apps. Excel I/O, 500+ calc functions, tables, charts, and more. View demosÂ now.

SpreadJS from MESCIUS inc sponsor

ğŸ†Â TypeScript Leaps to #1 Most Used Language on GitHub â€” As part of this weekâ€™s GitHub Universe event, GitHub released its annual report of activity on the platform. A year ago, Python jumped to #1, pushing JavaScript to #3, but this year TypeScript takes the crown and GitHub suggests LLM-oriented development played a role. Taking JavaScript and TypeScript together, however, places our ecosystem far out inÂ front.

GitHub

IN BRIEF:

  • Evan You has announced that VoidZero Inc., his company oriented around the Vite family of tools, has raised $12.5m in Series A funding.

  • Lizz Parody shares a quick update on the state of the Express.js project and its recent stepsÂ forward.

  • You've only got 24 hours left to take the State of JS 2025 survey.

  • Vercel now supports the Bun runtime.

RELEASES:

  • Node.js v24.11.0 (LTS) â€“ Node v24 transitions to the active LTS release and will be supported until April 2028. v22.21.1 (LTS) and v25.1 (Current) were also released thisÂ week.

  • Electron 39 â€“ The cross platform desktop app framework upgrades to Chromium 142, V8 14.2, and NodeÂ 22.20.

  • Ember 6.8 â€“ The long standing framework gains a new renderComponent API and Embroider and Vite by default for much fasterÂ builds.

  • Rspack 1.6, pnpm 10.20, Vite 7.2.0 Beta 1 (changelog), Three.js r181

ğŸ“–Â  Articles and Videos

I Built the Same App 10 Times: Evaluating Frameworks for Mobile Performance â€” When targeting mobile devices, small bundle sizes and quick rendering times are key, so Loren wanted to see how different approaches compared. Marko, SolidStart, SvelteKit, Qwik, Nuxt, Next.js and more are all under the spotlightÂ here.

Loren Stewart

â–¶Â Â The Origin Story of JavaScript â€” Annie takes us all the way back to the start of the Web in the early 90s and walks us through the conditions and advancements that enabled JavaScript to take off, all the way through to our modern framework-oriented, tool-rich ecosystem. (25Â minutes.)

Annie Sexton

Still Writing Tests Manually? â€” See why modern engineering teams like Dropbox, Notion and Wiz rely on Meticulous to run E2E UIÂ tests.

Meticulous AI sponsor

Why NaN !== NaN in JavaScript (and the IEEE 754 Story Behind It) â€” NaN is a number, but itâ€™s also Not a Number! This leads to some well-known quirky behavior, but JavaScript isnâ€™t toÂ blame.

Piotr Zarycki

What I Learned Porting Mastro from Deno to Node â€” Mastro is a site generator originally for Deno only. But if Deno is compatible with Node, is it easy to make Deno-facing code run on Node too? Not exactly, but itâ€™sÂ possible.

Mauro Bieg

ğŸ“„ Migrating from Node.js v22 to v24 â€“ Now that v24 is the active LTS release, it's time to upgrade when possible. Augustin Mauroy

ğŸ“„ Did You Know That There's an HTML Tables API? Christian Heilmann

ğŸ“„ Writing Rust-Like Code in TypeScript Andrew Israel

ğŸ› Â Code & Tools

Navcat: 3D Floor-Based Pathfinding Library â€” Itâ€™s not often we see a library with such a funny demo on the homepage (it involves cats and laser pointers!) Navcat is a pathfinding library, aimed at games and simulations, for enabling objects to route through 3D space. There are numerous other interesting demos too. GitHubÂ repo.

Isaac Mason

Introducing ArkRegex: It's RegExp() with Types â€” The idea is simple: swap out the RegExp constructor or regular expression literals for this typed wrapper and get types for patterns and capture groups. Part of the ArkType project. â€“ GitHubÂ repo.

ArkType Project

Measure and Improve the Quality of Code Generated by LLMs â€” Open source tool to fine tune prompts, compare model code quality, & monitor generated quality overÂ time.

Angular sponsor

Slim Select 3.0: An Advanced Select Dropdown Control â€” A feature-rich select dropdown component with no dependencies. v3.0 adds an official React component option, fixes bugs, and improvesÂ accessibility.

Brian Voelker

ğŸ¤«Â spoilerjs: Framework-Agnostic 'Spoiler Effects' â€” If youâ€™ve got some text (or maybe sensitive data like a token) you want to hide on a page until someone clicks on it, this Telegram-inspired web component is forÂ you.

shajid hasan

Gasket: CLI Tool to Discover 'Bridges' Between JavaScript and NativeÂ Code â€” Dynamic analysis tool that inspects the in-memory layout of JavaScript function objects to identify those that cross the language boundary. This is quite niche, but built by the authors of a paper about identifying such bridges for securityÂ purposes.

Alexopoulos and Sotiropoulos

>Â vue-command: A Terminal Emulator Component for Vue.js

Julian Claus

  • ğŸ“Š Recharts 3.3 â€“ A chart library built on top of D3. The homepage has examples andÂ demos. v3.3 gives charts the direct ability to handle responsiveÂ sizing.

  • ğŸ¦´ Cornerstone.js 4.8 â€“ Libraries for building medical imagingÂ apps.

  • ğŸ” fuzzy-search 2.0 â€“ Fast fuzzy search library for the frontend.

  • Immer 10.2 â€“ Popular library for working with immutable state.

  • Dependency Cruiser 17.2 â€“ Tool to visualizeÂ dependencies.

  • Ink 6.4 â€“ Use React to build CLIÂ apps.

ğŸ“°Â Classifieds

ğŸ”· Build a full-featured BPMN editor in record time â€” use our ready-made JointJS template and focus on innovation, notÂ implementation.

âš¡ UI changes? Catch them before prod. Vizzly = local TDD + review rules for teams, not justÂ screenshots.

ğŸ“¢Â  Elsewhere in the ecosystem

A roundup of some other interesting stories in the broader landscape:

  • vite-plugin-use-golang is a curious new Vite plugin that lets you add a "use golang" directive to the top of a 'JavaScript' file but then actually write Go codeÂ instead (which is then compiled toÂ WebAssembly).

  • VoidZero's Alexander Lichter rounds up everything that happened at ViteConf 2025 and shares updates on Vite+, Oxlint, Vite DevTools, Nitro v3, andÂ more.

  • Mirat Can Bayrak spied a site on Flippa that makes $200 a month from just 161 lines of JavaScript.

  • Node-RED is a popular 'low code' JavaScript-powered programming environment and Node-RED Con 2025 is a free, online event taking place next week (November 4) highlighting how it's used in engineering, smart homes, and even to play Factorio.
